meanings.def: to put something quickly into a liquid and take it out again
examples: dip something (into something) He dipped the brush into the paint.
dip something (in) Dip your hand in to see how hot the water is.
The fruit had been dipped in chocolate.
He dipped his finger in the water
Quickly dip the tomatoes in boiling water.
She dipped the brush lightly in the varnish.

meanings.def: to go downwards or to a lower level; to make something do this
examples: (+ adv./prep.) The sun dipped below the horizon.
Sales for this quarter have dipped from 38.7 million to 33 million.
The road dipped suddenly as we approached the town.
dip something (+ adv./prep.) The plane dipped its wings.
He dipped his head as he went through the doorway.
His head dipped towards her.
Support dipped sharply to 51 per cent.
The road dipped steeply down into the town.
The sun was slowly dipping out of sight.
hills which dip gently to the east
when unemployment dips below a certain point

meanings.def: if you dip your headlights when driving a car at night, you make the light from them point down so that other drivers do not have the light in their eyes
when farmers dip animals, especially sheep, they put them in a bath of a liquid containing chemicals in order to kill insects, etc.
to spend some of your own money on something
examples: She was forced to dip into her own pocket to pay for the repairs.

meanings.def: to start doing something very carefully to see if it will be successful or not
examples: We decided to dip a toe in the computer games market.

idioms.def: to spend some of your own money on something
examples: She was forced to dip into her own pocket to pay for the repairs.

idioms.idiom: dip a toe in/into something | dip a toe in/into the water
idioms.def: to start doing something very carefully to see if it will be successful or not
examples: We decided to dip a toe in the computer games market.
Let's go for a dip before breakfast.

meanings.def: a decrease in the amount or success of something, usually for only a short period
examples: Share prices have taken a slight dip.
dip in something a sharp dip in profits
The nation is experiencing an economic dip.
a sharp dip in temperature
the occasional dips in the market

meanings.def: a place where a surface suddenly drops to a lower level and then rises again
examples: a dip in the road
The village lay in a dip among the hills.
Puddles had formed in the dips.

meanings.def: a thick mixture into which pieces of food are dipped before being eaten
a liquid containing a chemical into which sheep and other animals can be dipped in order to kill insects on them

examples: A brief dip into history serves to confirm this view.

meanings.def: a quick movement of something down and up
examples: He gave a dip of his head.

meanings.def: a system in which documents are treated as images (the abbreviation for ‘document image processing’)
